conclusion: The problem involves analyzing how shadows A, B, C, and D change in position and size when the light source moves forward-and-right, away from the objects.
A general effect of moving the light forward is that all shadows are pushed backward (away from the viewer).
A general effect of moving the light to the right is that all shadows are pushed to the left.
Combining the forward and rightward motions of the light, every shadow drifts diagonally back-and-left on the floor.
As the light recedes (moves farther from the objects), the cone of rays becomes less divergent, causing every shadow to become slightly smaller and crisper.
Object A is a bust on a pedestal.
The shadow of object A slides noticeably back-and-left due to the light's movement.
The shadow of object A shrinks slightly because the bust is still fairly tall.
Object B is a thin vertical stone.
The shadow of object B drifts back-and-left, with the greatest distance among all objects because the stone is already high above the floor.
The shadow of object B shrinks the most noticeably because it is a tall, thin object.
Object C is a wide dress.
The shadow of object C moves back-and-left by a smaller amount than A or B because most of the dress is already low to the ground.
The shadow of object C experiences minor size reduction and remains the broadest shadow.
Object D is a paper plane.
The shadow of object D moves back-and-left by roughly the same vector as C because the plane is low to the ground.
The shadow of object D shrinks slightly, with the change being subtle because the plane is almost flat already.
After the lamp moves forward-and-right, every shadow shifts diagonally backward-and-left on the floor and all of them become slightly smaller.
The tallest objects (B, then A) show the largest position shift and the greatest size reduction, while lower objects (C, then D) shift and shrink less.
